text.__SUMMARY__: Grevillea bipinnatifida, also known as fuchsia grevillea, is a  shrub which is endemic to Western Australia.
text.Description:
This species forms a spreading shrub which grows up to 1 m (3 ft) 
in height. It has red or orange flowers which appear from early 
autumn to mid summer (March to January in Australia).
text.Distribution:
The species occurs in and around Perth on granite outcrops, hills and occasionally
on poorly draining flat areas.
text.Taxonomy:
The species was first formally described in 1830 by botanist 
Robert Brown.
Two subspecies are recognised:

Grevillea bipinnatifida R.Br. subsp. bipinnatifida
Grevillea bipinnatifida subsp. pagna Cranfield
text.Cultivars:
A number of hybrid cultivars have been produced which have Grevillea bipinnatifida as a parent species. These include a number of hybrids with Grevillea banksii including:

G.'Coconut Ice'
G. 'Claire Dee'
G. 'Peaches and Cream'
G. 'Robyn Gordon'
G. 'Superb'Other hybrids include:

G. 'Molly' (a cross with G. aurea)
G. 'Sunrise' (a cross with G. 'Clearview Robin')
text.References:
"Grevillea bipinnatifida". Flora of Australia Online. Department of the Environment and Heritage, Australian Government.
"Grevillea bipinnatifida". FloraBase. Western Australian Government Department of Parks and Wildlife.
Australian Plant Name Index (APNI): Grevillea bipinnatifida
